Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Potential Direct Geologic Constraint of Ice Sheet Thickness in the Central Transantarctic Mountains during the Pliocene Warm Period
Award.AbstractNarration:
This investigation will reconstruct past behavior of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet during periods of warmer-than-present climate, such as the Pliocene, in order to better project the likely response of Earth's largest ice sheet to anthropogenic warming. Containing the equivalent of ~55 m sea-level rise, the future evolution of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet has clear societal ramifications on a global scale as temperatures continue to rise. Therefore, determining ice-sheet sensitivity to climate on the scale predicted for the next two centuries is a matter of increasing urgency, particularly in light of evidence suggesting the East Antarctic Ice Sheet is more dynamic than previously thought. This research will provide a terrestrial geologic record of long-term ice-sheet behavior from sites immediately adjacent the East Antarctic Ice Sheet in the Transantarctic Mountains, with which the project will help ascertain how the ice sheet responded to past warm periods. The project will focus primarily on the Pliocene warm period, 5 to 3 million years ago, as this represents the closest analogue to 21st Century climate conditions.

The proposed research will investigate glacial deposits corresponding to the East Antarctic Ice Sheet in the central Transantarctic Mountains in order to expand the geologic record of past ice-sheet behavior. The overarching research objectives are to improve understanding of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet's configuration during periods of warmer-than-present climate, such as the Pliocene warm period, and to determine whether the ice sheet underwent significant volume changes or remained relatively stable in response to warming. To address these goals, the investigation will map and date glacial deposits preserved at mountain sites immediately adjacent the ice sheet. Specifically, we will: (i) employ multiple cosmogenic nuclides (10Be, 26Al, 21Ne) to establish more fully ice-thickness histories for the upper Shackleton and Beardmore Glaciers, where they exit the ice sheet; (ii) use this record to identify periods during which the East Antarctic Ice Sheet was at least as extensive as today; and (iii) use these data to assess long-term ice-sheet variability in East Antarctica, with particular emphasis on Pliocene warm episodes. This research will require Antarctic fieldwork, glacial-geologic mapping, and cosmogenic surface-exposure dating.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to (1) establish how the East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS) responds to climate warming, by reconstructing ice sheet behavior during past warm periods, and (2) deliver much-needed terrestrial calibrations for frontline models simulating future change, data that until now have been scarce from the Antarctic continent itself. The EAIS represents the greatest potential source of future sea level rise. Assessing the sensitivity of Earth?s largest ice sheet therefore is a key objective for climate change adaptation and mitigation.

 

The primary scientific outcome of this project is a geologic record of ice sheet fluctuations (thickening and thinning) that spans the last ~15 million years. The record is built on relict glacial deposits at two sites in the central Transantarctic Mountains ? Roberts Massif and Otway Massif ? adjacent the center of the ice sheet, and is dated with multiple types of cosmogenic surface-exposure methods. Overall, this new record reveals how the surface of the EAIS in this central region has changed over time. Relative to the modern landscape, our findings show that the ice sheet surface was slightly higher during earlier parts of our record (e.g., the warm Miocene) and has lowered gradually over ~15 million years. The most striking aspect of the record, however, is that is shows the EAIS has remained largely unchanged for a very long period. Focusing on the Pliocene (5?2.6 million years ago), parts of which are thought to be analogous to modern global warming, our record suggests the ice sheet was generally present during that time but that there is a conspicuous ?gap? during the middle Pliocene. Whether or not that gap indicates the EAIS shrank due to climate warming has key implications for our understanding of ice sheet stability and will be tested with additional geologic investigations on the continent.

 

As the coldest and driest continent on Earth, Antarctica is well known for low rates of weathering and erosion. Through our use of multiple cosmogenic nuclides, a second scientific outcome of this project is quantification of the long-term erosion rate for the central Transantarctic Mountains, which we has established as < 5 cm/million years. This is important information for future research into the geology, glaciology, and climate of Antarctica.

 

The glacial-geologic record for Roberts Massif, including geomorphic maps, cosmogenic ages, weathering rate calculations, and a discussion of the record?s scientific implications, was published (August 2020) in the open-access journal The Cryosphere(https://tc.copernicus.org/articles/14/2647/2020/tc-14-2647-2020-discussion.html). A second paper, documenting the glacial-geologic record from Otway Massif, is currently in progress and will be submitted for open-access publication in 2021. All geochronologic data produced are available via the online ICE-D: Antarctica database, for free use and re-evaluation by public/scientific users. Project findings have also been presented at three international conferences.

 

Complementing the scientific deliverables, this project fulfilled its commitment to the education of students and training of the next generation of scientists. Specifically, one undergraduate participated in fieldwork during the 2015-16 Antarctic season, after which she traveled to Berkeley Geochronology Center to assist with the measurement of geochronology samples. These experiences formed the basis for her undergraduate thesis at UMaine. One graduate student participated in fieldwork during the 2016-17 Antarctic season and was trained in the preparation and measurement of cosmogenic geochronology samples. The student took the lead in preparing the project?s first paper for publication (of which she is lead author), and is now pursuing a PhD in geochemistry. The project also enabled a second graduate student to receive training in Antarctic fieldwork and glacial geology. This student (since awarded a Marie Sklodowska-Curie Actions postdoctoral fellowship) took responsibility for constructing the young end of our Roberts Massif record, which we anticipate will be published in 2021.

 

From the outset, project findings have been incorporated into undergraduate curricula both at UMaine and Dartmouth College. Project team members have delivered distilled age-appropriate versions of findings and research experiences to K-12 audiences, including elementary/middle schools in Maine and high schools in Massachusetts, and also via the Skype-a-Scientist initiative. Beyond the classroom, the PI has included artwork and photography stemming from project fieldwork in three art exhibitions since 2017, including two in Maine and one in Ireland, with the overarching objective of bringing publicly funded science to a public audience via art. All three have been well received and were used widely by elementary schools to introduce the rationale for science.

 

The project delivered:

-        A 15 million-year geologic record of EAIS fluctuations in the central Transantarctic Mountains, including maps and chronologic data;

-        Constraint on long-term Antarctic weathering rates;

-        One open-access publication to date (two more anticipated in 2021) and full online storage of data;

-        Training of one female undergraduate and two female graduate students in field-based geology;

-        Interactive dissemination of findings and experiences to K-12 and university students;

-        Public exhibitions of science-inspired art.
